CCCCXVIII.  BuU  of  Pope  Clement  VI.  setting  furth  that  he  had  reserved  for  his  own  dis- 
posal  the  provision  to  the  church  of  Brechin,  held  by  the  deceased  Adam, 
Bishop  of  Brechin,  on  its  bccoming  vacant ;  that,  afterwards,  however,  on  tlie 
death  of  Bishop  Adam,  the  chapter  of  that  church,  in  ignorance  of  this  reser- 
vation,  had  unanimously  elected  Philip  dean  of  that  church,  who  was  in  the 
order  of  the  priesthood,  to  be  Bishop  ;  that  the  said  Philip,  in  the  like  igno- 
rance,  had  consenteJ  to  the  election,  but,  on  being  informed  of  the  ahove  re- 
servatiouj  had  come  before  the  Apostolic  See  and  explained  the  matter  to  the 
Pope  in  consistory  ;  that  the  Pope,  then,  holding  this  election  to  be  invalid,  as 
being,  de  facto,  attempted  to  be  carried  through  after  and  in  the  face  of  the 
foresaid  reservation,  yet  being  anxious  to  pi'eserve  that  church  from  the  incon- 
venienees  of  a  prolonged  vacancy,  and  having  earuestly  considered  the  said 
Philip's  virtues  and  knowledge  of  letters,  for  wliich  he  was  commended,  and 
the  unanimous  election  of  the  chapter,  after  careful  deliberation  with  his 
brethren,  appoints  him  Bishop  of  the  Church  of  Brechin,  committing  to  liini 
the  care  of  its  spiritual  and  temporal  affairs,  in  the  full  confidence  that  it  would 
be  prosperously,  humhly,  and  devotedly  governed  by  him.  Dated  at  Avinion, 
in  the  eighth  year  of  the  Pope's  consecration,  20th  February.    [A.D.  1350.] 

Mandates  to  the  chapter,   clergy,  and  people  of  the   city  and  diocese  of 
Brechin,  to  receive  the  said  Philip  elect  of  Brechin  as  their  Bishop  and  the

CCCCXIX.  Bull  of  Pope  Clement  VI.  in  the  same  terms,  and  gi-anted  for  the  same  reasons

CCCCXX.  Bull  by  Innocent  VI.  in  favour  of  William  de  Grenlaw,  Archdeacon  of  Brechin 
and  Master  of  Arts,  ordering  the  execution  of  a  Bull  emitted  by  Clement  VI. 
on  the  second  of  March,  in  the  seventh  year  of  his  pontificate,  which  reserved 
for  his  own  collation  and  disposal  the  Archdeaconry  of  Brechin,  then  held  by 
Donald  de  Marre  the  last  Archdeacon,  as  soon  as  the  same  should  become 
vacant,  and  stated  that,  after  the  said  Archdeaconry  had  become  vacant  by  the 
decease  of  the  said  Donald,  who  died  extra  Eomanam  mnam,  a  certain  Lau- 
rence  de  Erole,  deporting  himself  as  Archdeacon  of  the  said  church,  had  for  a 
year  and  more  held  and  continued  to  hold  the  said  Archdeaconry  on  the 
pretext  of  a  certain  eoUation  made  by  authority  of  the  ordinary  in  his  favour, 
while  no  one  had  power  to  dispose  thereof  but  the  said  Pope  Clement,  who 


LITERAE    PAPALES,  395 

being  desirous  to  confer  a  special  favour  ou  the  said  William  de  Grenlaw,  a 
proficient  in  Canon  Law,  and  well  commended  to  the  Pope,  on  the  testimouy 
of  trustwortliy  persons,  for  his  knowledge  of  letters,  the  probity  of  his  life  and 
morals,  and  other  meritorious  and  virtuous  deserts,  had,  for  these  reasons,  and 
for  the  sake  of  Johanna,  Queen  of  Scotland,  who  besought  the  said  Pontitf  ou 
behalf  of  the  said  William  de  Grenlaw,  her  beloved  clerk,  on  the  twenty- 
seventh  day  of  February  of  the  tenth  year  of  his  Pontificate,  bestowed  on  the 
said  William  de  Grenlaw  the  foresaid  vacant  Archdeaconry  with  all  its  rights 
and  pertinents,  dispensing  with  all  constitutions,  statutes,  and  customs  of  the 
churches  of  Brechin  and  Glasgow  to  the  eontrary  ;  and  notwithstanding  he 
held  a  canonry,  in  the  expectation  of  a  prebend,  in  the  church  of  Aberdeen, 
besides  the  deanery  of  Glasgow,  impowering  him  to  hold  the  said  Archdeaconry 
in  conjunction  with  the  said  Deanery  ;  it  being  provided  by  both  Popes  that 
the  said  Archdeaconry  and  Deanery  should  not  be  defrauded  of  the  services 
due  to  them.  Dated  at  Villanova,  in  the  diocese  of  Avinion,  20th  May,  iu 
the  first  year  of  the  Pope's  consecration.     [A.D.  1353.] 

Mandate  following  thereon,  directing  the  Bishops  of  Glasgow  and  Ross,  and 
the  Sacristan  of  the  church  of  Avinion,  to  induct  the  said  WilHam  de  Grenlaw 
into  the  corporal  possession  of  the  said  Arehdeacom"y,  with  all  the  rights  and 
emoluments  belonging  thereto.     Dated  as  above.

pro  parte  dilecti  filii  Johannis  de  Mongombro  laici  et  dilecte  in  Christo  filie

possent  invicem  matrimonialiter  copulari,  matrimonium  per  verba  de  presenti 
in  facie  ecclesie,  nemine  se  opponente,  invicem  publice  conti-axerunt,  illudque

autem  postmodum,  sicut  eadem  petitio  subjungebat,  ad  ipsorum  Johannis  et

conjuncti,  propter  quod  in  sic  contracto  matrimonio  licite  remanere  [non

dispensationis  beneficio  dignaremur  .  Nos,  itaque,  hujusmodi  eorum  supplica-

CCCCXXII.  Indulgence  by  Innocent  VI.  to  William  de  Greenlaw  Archdeacon  of  St. 
Andrews  and  Master  in  Arts,  to  retain  the  said  Archdeaconry,  which  the  Pope 
had  by  a  prior  Bull  conferred  upon  him,  and  the  Deanery  of  Glasgow,  which 
the  said  prior  Bull  had  held  him  bound  to  demit,  in  conjunction  witli  a  canonry 
and  prebend  in  thc  church  of  Moray ;  providing,  however,  that  the  sald  Arch- 
deaconry  and  Deanery  were  not  defrauded  of  the  services  due  to  them  ;  it 
having  been  required  by  the  saiJ  prior  Bull  that,  having  obtained  the  Arch- 
deaconry  of  St.  Andrews,  he  should  resign  all  right  to  the  Archdeaconry  of 
Brechin,  to  which  he  had  been  provided,  on  its  being  vacant,  although  he 
never  obtained  possession  of  it.  DateJ  at  Villanova  in  the  diocese  of  Avignon, 
6th  June,  in  the  fifth  year  of  the  Pope's  consecration,     [A.D.  1367.]

dilectum  filium  Thomam  Myrtouum  decanum  Glasguensem  oratores  tuae  sere- 
nitatis  ad  nos  accedentes  cum  literis  tuis  libenter  vidimus,  et  grato  animo  audi- 


LITERAE    PAPALES.  397 

vimus  ea  que  ex  ipsius  serenitatis  parte  exposuerunt ;  nobis  fuerunt  enim  grata 
admodum  que  de  tuo  bono  statu  et  prosperitate  dixerunt,  et  de  tua  erga  nos  et 
Sedem  Apostolicam  deuotione  .  Cum  enim  diligamus  personam  tuae  celsitudinis 
tanquam  peculiarem  nostrum  et  ecclesiae  filium  caritate  paterna,  merito  letamur 
in  Domino  quando  referuntur  auribus  nostris  ea  que  cupimus  de  tua  sublimi- 
tate  .  In  his  autem  que  prefati  oratores  postularunt  a  nobis  quantum  cum  Deo 
potuimus  et  honore  nostro  exaudire  conati  sumus  tua  nota ;  concessimus  enim 
tibi  inter  cetera  medietam  omnium  pecuniarum  que  ad  nos  spectant  et  debentur 
nobis  usque  ad  Festum  Resurrectiouis  Domini  nostri  Jhesu  Christi  proxime  pre- 
teriti,  ut  tua  devotio  possit  cum  illis  tuis  necessitatibus  succurrere  .  Vellemus 
ut  ecclesia  esset  in  eo  statu  ut  possemus  ampliora  facere,  sed  multa  nos  urgeut 
undique  ut  quod  pro  tua  serenitate  optaremus  facere  nequeamus  .  De  his  vero 
que  spectant  ad  venerabiles  fratres  nostros  Sanctae  Romanae  Ecclesiae  Cardi- 
nales,  remissionem  facere  non  possumus  cum  honore  nostro  .  Nulla  enim 
honestas  patitur  nos  bona  alterius  remittere  vel  donare  .  Ceterum  oratores  ipsi 
revertuntur  cum  benedictione  nostra  plenius  informati  ad  serenitatem  tuam, 
cui  circa  status  sui  regnique  conservationem  ac  pacem  et  quietem  in  singulis 
paterna  benevolentia  cupimus  complacere  .  Datum  Rome,  etc.  .  [A.D.  1417-31.] 


CCCCXXIV.  Indulgence  by  Nicolas  V.  narrating  that  by  certain  letters  he  had  ordered 
Andrew  de  Fiffe,  perpetual  vicar  of  the  parish  church  of  Marynton  in  the 
diocese  of  Brechin  and  Master  in  Arts,  to  be  provided,  od  accouat  of  his  know- 
ledge  of  letters,  the  probity  of  his  life  and  uiorals,  and  other  praisewortliy  and 
meritorious  deserts,  with  one  or  two  ecclesiastical  benetices,  then  vacant  or  to 
become  vacant,  in  the  presentation  of  the  Bishops  of  Dunkeld  and  Brechin,  and 
the  deans,  archdeacons,  chapters,  canons,  and  parsons  thereof,  although  one 
of  these  benefices  should  have  a  cure,  or  should  be  a  dignity  or  office  in  a 
cathedral,  or  either  of  them  a  canonry  anJ  prebend  in  a  collegiate  church,  but 
not  the  next  after  the  episcopal  dignity,  providing  the  emoluments  of  one  or 
both,  if  with  cure,  should  not  exceed  twenty-five,  or  if  without  cure,  eighteen 
marks  sterling  yearly ;  and,  farther,  of  liis  own  accord,  and  not  at  the  request  of 


398  LITERAE    PAPALES. 

the  said  Andrew  de  Fiffe,  or  of  any  other  on  his  behalf,  estending  the  appli- 
cation  of  the  saids  letters  to  a  benefiee  or  benefices  in  the  presentation  of  the 
Abbot  and  Convent  of  the  Monastery  of  St.  Thomas  the  martyr  of  Abbribroth 
of  the  order  of  St.  Beuedict  in  the  diocese  of  St.  Andrews,  although  the  said 
benefice  or  benefices  were  wont  to  be  assigned  to  seeular  clerks  ;  of  new  giving 
him  power  to  accept  of  such  benefice  or  benefices  when  vacant ;  impowering 
the  executors  of  the  BuU  also  to  provide  him  thereto  ;  and  authorising  him  to 
hold  the  same   in  conjunction  vvitli  the  perpetual  vicarage  of  the  said  parish 
church  of  Marynton  then  held  by  him,  the  revenues  of  which  did  not  exceed  the 
annual  value  of  six  pounds  sterling,  or  on  his  demission  thereof  to  hold  any  two 
other  incompatible  benefices,  even  if  they  are  parish  churches  or  their  perpetual 
vicarages  or  dignities  or  ofiices  in  cathedrals  or  metropolitan  and  coUegiate 
churches,  although  such  dignities  in  the  cathedrals  and  nietropolitan  churches 
should  be  the  next  after  the  episcopal,  or  have  the  cure  of  souls,  or  be  incom- 
patible  in  any  other  manner  whatever ;  the  parish  churches  and  tbeir  vicarages 
and  such  like  being  held  alternately  during  seven  years,  and  the  others  for 
life ;  impowering  him  also  to  demit  the  same  at  his  pleasure,  and  to  accept  and 
hold  in  the  same  manner  other  similar  or  dissimilar  benefices,  and  that  not- 
withstanding  a  certain  ordinance  was  formerly  issued  by  the  said  Pope  prohibit- 
ing  any  persons,  except  those  therein  mentioned,  of  vi^hom  the  said  Andrew  de 
Fiffe  is  not  one,  from  holding  such  incompatible  benefices ;  dispensiug  also 
with  all  Apostolical  constitutions,  or  other  statutes  and  customs  of  churches 
contrary  hereto  ;  it  being  provided,  however,  that  the  saids  vicarage  and  incom- 
patible  benefices  shall  not  be  defrauded  of  the  services  due  to  them  and  of  the 
cure  of  souls,  and  that  the  vicarage  shall  not  be  neglected ;  and  willing,  more- 
over,  that  the  said  Andrew  de  Fiffe,  when  he  wishes  to  exchange  one  of  these 
two  parish  churclies  or  vicarages  for  another  ecclesiastical  benefice,  shall  be 
bound  wholly  to  demit,  within  the  foresaid  space  of  seven  years,  that  one  of 
them  which  he  first  obtained,  and  which,  it  is  declared,  should  be  vacant  at  the 
end  of  the  said  space.     Dated  at  St.  Peter's,  at  Rome,  14th  June,  in  the  first 
year  of  the  Pope's  pontificate.     [1447.]

CCCCXXV.  Nicolau.s  V.  etc.  .  Venerabilibus  fratribus  AncoBitansi  et  Brechinensi  Episcopis,

liberales  .  Hodie  siquidem  motu  proprio  singulos  primo  vacaturos  singularum 
Dunkeldensis  et  Moraviensis  ecclesiarum  canonicatus  et  prebendas  collationi  et

in  nostris  inde  confectis  litteris  plenius  continetur  .  Nos  igitur  volentes  dicto 
Willermo,  qui,  ut  accepimus,  carissimo  in  Cbristo  filio  nostro  Jacobo  Regi 
Scotie  illustri  in  secundo  et  tertio  consanguinitatis  gradibus  conjunetus,  ac 
venerabilis  ft'atris  nostri  Jacobi  Episcopi  Sancti  Andree  nepos  existit,  premis- 
sorum  meritorum  suorum  intuitu  gratiam  facere  specialem  motu  simili,  non  ad 
ipsius  Willermi  vel  alterius  pro  eo  nobis  super  hoc  oblate  petitionis  instantiam, 
sed  de  nostra  mera  hberalitate,  discretioni  vestre  per  apostolica  scripta  man- 
damus,  quatinus  vos,  vel  duo  aut  unus  vestrum,  per  vos,  vel  aliura  seu  alios, 
canonicatus  et  prebendas  predictos  cum  simul  vel  successive  vacaverint  cum 
plenitudine  juris  canonici  ac  omnibus  juribus  et  pertinentiis  suis  prefato  Wil- 
lermo  auctoritate  nostra  conferre  et  assignare  curetis  .  .  .  facientes  Willer- 
mum,  vel  pro  ipso  procuratorem  predictum,  ad  singulas  prebendas  hujusmodi 
in  dictis  ecclesiis  in  canonicum  recipi  etc.  .  .  .  Datum  Rome,  apud  Sanctum 
Petrum,  anno  Domini  millesimo  quadringentesimo  quadragesimo  sexto,  vi  Idus 
Martii,  Pontificatus  nostri  anno  tertio  .  [A.D.  1449  ?] 


CCCCXXVI.  Indulgence  by  Nicolas  V.  to  Robert  de  Seras,  a  layman  of  the  diocese  of 
Brechin,  who  in  his  youth  had  contracted  marriage  per  verha  de  presenti  with 
a  widow  since  dead,  by  whom  he  had  had  several  children,  but  being  possessed 
of  learning,  was  now  anxious  to  live  in  continence,  to  be  enrolled  for  clerical 
service,  and  to  serve  the  Most  High  for  ever,  allowing  him  to  receive  and  hold 


400  LITERAE    PAPALES. 

tAvo  simple  ecclesiastical  benefices,  although  they  were  canonries  or  prebends 
in  cathedral  or  collegiate  churches,  provided  they  were  canonically  conferred 
on  him,  and  were  not  defrauded  of  the  services  due  to  them.  Dated  at  St. 
Peter's,  at  Rome,  21st  February,  1449. 


Collatio  Walteri  Stevart  decanatui  Ecclesie  Brechinensis  . 

CCCCXXVII.  Nicolaus  V.  etc.  dilecto  filio  Waltero  Stevart  decano  ecclesie  Brechinensis  in 
utroque  jure  bacallario  Salutem  etc.  .  Nobilitas  generis,  litterarum  scientia, 
vite  ac  niorum  honestas,  aliaque  laudabilia  probitatis  et  virtutum  merita,  super 
quibus  apud  nos  fidedigno  commendaris  testimonio,  nos  inducunt  ut  tibi  redda- 
mur  ad  gratiam  liberales  .  Dudum  siquidem  omnes  dignitates  in  cathedralibus 
ecclesiis  post  pontificales  majores  tunc  vacantes  et  in  ante  vacaturas  collationi 
et  dispositioni  uostre  i'eservamus  .  .  .  Cum  itaque  postmodum  decanatus 
ecclesie  Brechinensis,  qui  dignltas  major  post  pontificalem  existit,  et  quem 
quondam  David  Crannoch,  ipsius  ecclesie  decanus,  dum  viveret  obtinebat,  per 
obitum  ejusdem  David,  qui  extra  Romanam  curiam  diem  clausit  extremum, 
vacaverit,  et  vacet  ad  presens  .  .  .  Nos  volentes  tibi,  qui,  ut  asseris,  de  nobili 
genere  procreatus,  ac  carissimi  in  Christo  filii  nostri  Jacobi  Scotorum  regis 
illustris  consanguineus  existis  .  .  .  gratiam  facere  specialem,  ac  omnia  et 
singula  beneficia  ecclesiastica  cum  cura  et  sine  cura,  que  etiam  ex  quibusvis 
apostolicis  dispensationibus  obtines  et  expectas,  ac  in  quibus  et  ad  que  jus 
tibi  quomodolibet  competit,  quecumque,  quotcumque,  et  qualiacumque  fuerint, 
eorumque  fructuum  .  .  .  veros  annuos  valoi*es  ad  dispensationum  hujusmodi 
tenores  presentibus  pro  expressis  habentes,  decanatum  predictum,  ad  quem  quis 
per  electionem  assumi  consuevit,  et  cui  cura  immineat  animarum,  ac  cuius 
fructus  .  .  .  triginta  librarum  sterlingorum  secundum  communem  extimationem 
valorem  annuum,  ut  etiam  asseris,  non  excedunt  .  .  .  cum  omnibus  juribus  et 
pertinentiis  suis,  apostolica  tibi  auctoritate  conferimus,  et  de  illo  etiam  provi- 
demus  .  .  .  et  nihilominus  venerabili  fratri  nostro  Episcopo  Sancti  Andree,  et 
dilectis  filiis  Sancti  Andree  et  Brechinensi  oificialibus  per  apostoliea  scripta 
mandamus,  quatinus  ipsi  .  .  .  te,  vel  procuratorem  tuum  tuo  nomine,  recepto 


LITERAE    PAPALES.  401 

tamen  prius  a  te,  juxta  formam  inferius  annotatam,  nostro  et  Romane  Ecelesie 
nomine,  fidelitatis  debite  solito  juramento,  in  corporalem  possessionem  deca- 
natus  juriumque  et  pertinentiarum  predictorum  inducant  auctoritate  nostra,  et 
defendant  inductum   .  .  .  Volumus  autem  quod,  quamprimum  dicti  decanatus 
possessionem  fueris  vigore  presentium  pacificam  assecutus,  canonicatum  ecclesie 
Aberdonensis  et  prebendam  de  Bancbredeuony  in  eadem,  quoruni  fructus  . 
(juindecim  librarum  Sterlingorum  similium  secundum  extimationem  predictam 
valorem  annuum,  ut  similiter  asseris,  non  excedunt,  et  quos  inter  cetera  obtines, 
quosque  extunc  vacare  deceruimus  omnino,  prout  etiam  ad  id  te  sponte  obtulisti, 
dimittere  tenearis  .  Formam  autem  juramenti  predicti,   ut  per  eara   plenius 
informeris,  presentibus  inseri  fecimus,  cujus  tenor  de  verbo  ad  verbum  sequitur, 
et  est  talis  : — Ego  Waltei'us  Stewart  decanus  ecclesie  Brechinensis  ab  hac  hora, 
ut  in  antea,  fidelis  et  obediens  ero  beato  Petro,  sancteque  Apostolice  Romane 
Ecclesie,  ac  domino  meo  domino  Nicolao  Pape  V.  et  ejus  successoribus  canonice 
intrantibus  :  non  ero  iu  concilio,  consensu,  tractatu,  vel  facto,  ut  vitam  perdant 
aut  membrum,  seu  quod  contra  alicujus  eorum  personam,  vel  in  ipsorum  aiit 
ecclesie  ejusdem    sive    Sedis   Apostolice  auctoritatis,   honoris,    privilegiorum, 
jurium,   vel  apostolicorum  statutorum,  ordinationum,  reservationum,  disposi- 
tionum,  seu  mandatorum,   derogationem  vel   prejudicium,  machinationes  aut 
conspirationes  fiant ;  et  si  ac  quotiens  aliquod  horum  tractari  .scivero,  id  ne 
fiat  pro  posse  impediam,  et  quamtocius  commode  potero  eidem  domino  nostro, 
vel  alteri  per  quem  ad  ipsius  notitiam  pervenire  possit,  significabo  ;  consilium, 
vero,  quod  mihi  per  se  aut  nuncios  seu  litteras  credituri  sunt,  ad  eorum  damp- 
num,  me  sciente,  nemini  pandam  ;   ad  retinendum  ct  defendendum  Papatum 
Romanum   et  regalia   Sancti   Petri   contra  omnem  hominem  adjutor  eis  ero ; 
auctoritatem,  honorem,  privilegia  et  jura,  quantum  in  me  fuerit,  potius  augere 
et  promovere,  statuta,  ordinationes,  reservationes,   dispositiones,  et  mandata 
hujusmodi  observare,  et  eis  intendere  curabo ;  legatos  sedis  ejusdem  honorifice 
tractabo,  et  in  suis  necessitatibus  adjiivabo;  hereticos  ac  scismaticos,  ut  qui 
alieui  ex  Domino  nostro  successoribusque  predictis  rebelles  fuerint,  pro  viribus 
persequar  et  impugnabo  .  Sic  me  Deus  adjuvet,  et  hec  Sancta  Dei  Evangelia 
.   .  .  Datum  Rome,  apud  Sanctum  Petrum,  anno  incarnationis  Dorainice  mil- 
lesimo  quadringentesimo  quinquagesimo  quarto,  tertio  decimo  Kalendas  Maii, 
Pontificatus  nostri  anno  octavo  .

402  LITERAE    PAPALES. 


CCCCXXVIII.  Indulgence  by  Nicolas  V.  to  William  Forbes  dean  of  Brecbin,  narrating 
that  he  had  reserved  to  his  own  disposal  all  the  greater  dignities  that 
were  or  should  be  vacant  in  cathedral  churches  exeept  the  episcopal  ;  that  the 
deanery  of  the  church  of  Brechin,  being  the  principal  dignity  therein  and 
formerly  held  by  Walter  Steuart,  was  vacant  by  his  decease  extra  Eomanam 
curiam  /  that  the  said  William  Forbes  was  about  twenty  years  of  age,  a  kins- 
man  of  James  King  of  Scots,  of  baronial  family,  a  student  at  Paris,  and  a 
nephevv  of  James  bishop  of  St.  Andrews,  who  desired  for  him  some  mark  of 
special  favour;  therefore  conferring  on  the  said  William  Forbes  the  said 
deanery  of  Brechin,  to  which  it  was  customary  for  one  to  be  iutroduced  by 
election,  which  had  the  cure  of  souls,  the  revenues  of  v/hich  did  not  exceed 
thirty  pounds  sterling  yearly,  and  which  was  vacant  by  the  death  or  resignation 
of  the  foresaid  Walter  and  of  David  Cramnok,  or  by  the  constitution  of  Pope 
John  XXII.  begiiining  "  Execrabilis  ;"  dispensing  with  the  constitutions  of 
Pope  Boniface  VIII.,  and  all  otlier  Apostolic  constitutions,  as  also  the 
statutes  and  customs  of  the  said  church,  though  ccnfirmed  by  oath,  apostolic 
confirmation,  or  aiiy  other  powor,  if  contrary  to  this  indulgence ;  willing  him 
to  be  preferred  to  all  others  claiming  right  to  this  deanery  by  special  or 
general  letters  of  the  Apostolic  See  or  its  legates,  but  without  prejudice 
to  the  acquirement  by  such  parties  of  other  dignities  or  benefices ;  declaring 
that  the  Bishop  and  Chapter  of  Brechin  sliould  in  nowise  be  bound  to  receive 
any  other  on  accouut  of  any  indulgence  granted  by  the  said  See,  nor  be  inter- 
dicted  nor  excommunicated  therefor,  and  that  none  should  be  provided  to  the 
dignities  of  the  said  church  or  other  ecclesiastical  benefices  belonging  to  the 
coUation  of  the  said  Bishop  and  Chapter  by  Apostolic  letters,  if  such  letters  did 
not  make  express  mention  of  this  indulgencc,  or  by  means  of  any  other  general 
or  special  indulgence  of  the  said  See  of  whatever  tenor,  by  which  the  efiFect  of 
this  indulgence  might  be  impeded  or  delayed  ;  allowing  him,  if  absent,  to  give 
the  usual  oath  for  observing  the  statutes  and  constitutions  of  the  said  church 
by  a  suitable  procurator,  until  ho  should  personally  give  it  thereat;  dispensing 
v.-ith  the  defect  of  Lis  age ;  but  providing  always  that  tlie  deanery  should  not 
be  defrauued  of  the  .services  due  to  it ;  and  giving  mandate  to  the  Prior  and 


LITERAE    PAPALES.  403 

Official  of  St.  Andrews  and  to  tlie  Archdeacon  of  Dumblane  to  iuduct  liim  into 
the  possession  of  the  said  deanery  accordingly.  Dated  at  St.  Petei''s,  at  Rome, 
in  the  eighth  year  of  the  Pope'3  consecration,  8th  October,  1454. 


CCCCXXIX.  Presentation,  iii  like  manner,  by  Pope  Nicolas  V.  in  favour  of  Hugh  de 
Douglas,  a  clerk  of  the  diocese  of  St.  Andrews,  and  of  noble  race  by  botli 
parents,  to  a  canoni-y  in  the  church  of  Brechin  and  the  prebend  of  Guthen 
therein,  with  their  revenues  not  exceeding  sis  pounds  sterling  yearly,  whieh 
the  Pope  had  reserved  to  his  own  collation  in  the  event  of  their  being  resigned 
by  the  foresaid  William  Forbes  on  his  attaining  the  deanery  of  the  said 
church,  because  they  could  not  be  held  in  conjunction  therewith.  Dated  at 
St.  Peter's,  at  Rome,  8tli  October,  in  the  eighth  year  of  the  Pope's  pontificate, 
1454.

CCCCXXXI.  Bull  by  Calistus  III.  directed  to  the  bisbops  of  Alexandria  and  Dunkeld  and 
the  Dean  of  Dunkeld,  narrating  that  his  predecessor,  Nicolas  V.,  had,  on  the 
20th  of  September,  1453,  given  orders  to  confer,  in  preference  to  all  others, 
on  the  said  Gilbert  Forstar,  archdeacon  of  Brechin,  the  pei'petual  vicarage 
of  the  parish  church  of  Dunde,  in  the  diocese  of  Brechin,  with  its  revenues 
not  exceeding  thirty  pounds  sterling  yearly,  when  it  should  become  vacant 
by  the  resignation  of  Richard  de  Crag  vicar  thereof,  or  by  the  constitution 
of  Pope  John  XXII.  beginning  "  Execrabiiis,"  provided  no  one  had  esta- 
blished  a  legal  right  thereto,  and  that  even  although  the  said  Gilbert  was 
known  to  hold  tbe  archdeaconry  of  Brechin  and  a  canonry  and  prebend  in 
the  church  of  Moray  called  the  subchantorship,  the  [imited]  revenues  of  which 
did  not  exceed  the  value  of  sixty  pounds  sterling  yearly ;  and  had  impowered 
the  said  Gilbert  to  retain  these  or  any  other  incompatible  ecclesiastical  bene- 
fice  or  benefices  together,  provided  two  of  them  were  not  parish  churches, 
and  to  demit  them  for  others  of  the  like  kind  :  that  the  said  vicarage  belonged 
to  the  collation  of  the''Apostolic  See  according  to  the  statutes  of  the  Lateran 
Council ;  that  the  said  vicarage  was  vacant  by  the  decease  of  the  said  Richard 
de  Crag  extra  Bomanam  curiam  ;  therefore  willing  that  the  letters  of  the  said 
Pope  Nicolas  V.  should  obtain  their  due  effect,  and  giving  orders  to  the  above 
mentioned  bishops  and  dean  to  execute  the  same,  and  to  induct  the  said 
Gilbert  Forstar  into  the  corporal  possession  of  the  said  vicarage  with  its 
emoluments.    Dated  at  St.  Peter's,  at  Rome,  20th  April,  1455. 


LITERAE    PAPALES.  407

Provisio  Ricardi  Wyly  ad  archidiaconatum  Brechinensem  . 

CCCCXXXIII.  Pius  II.  etc.  .  Venerabilibus  fratribus  Sancti  Andree  et  Siluensi  Episcopis 
ac  dilecto  filio  officiali  Aberdonensi  Salutem  etc.  .  Literarum  scientia  vite  ac 
morum  honestas  aliaque  laudabilia  probitatis  et  virtutum  merita,  super  quibus 
apud  nos  dilectus  filius  Ricardus  Wyly,  presbyter  Brechinensis  diocesis,  ma- 
gister  in  artibus,  fidedigno  commendatur  testimonio,  nos  inducunt  ut  sibi  red- 
damur  ad  gratiam  liberales  .  Exhibita  siquidem  nobis  nuper  pro  parte  dicti 
Ricardi  petitio  continebat,  quod  olim  ad  audientiara  .  .  .  Calisti  Pape  III. 
predecessoris  nostri,  eodem  Ricardo  deferente,  deducto  quod  quidam  Gilbertus 
Forster,  olim  archidiaconus  ecclesie  Brechinensis,  clericalibus  decentia  et  man- 
suetudine  prorsus  abjectis,  spirituque  obstinatus  dictus,  in  bone  memorie 
Johannem  episcopum  Brechinensem  manus  ausu  saerilego  in  dicta  ecclesia  in- 
jecerat  temere  violentas,  et  propterea  excommunicationis  sententia  in  tales  a 
canone  generaliter  promulgata  innodatua  se  divinis  officiis  immiscere  presump- 
serat,  in  anime  sue  periculum,  clericalis  dignitatis  opprobrium,  ac  plurimorum 
scandalum  perniciosum  pariter  exeraplum  .  Idem  predecessor  attendens  quod  si 
esset  ita,  predictus  Gilbertus  archidiaconatu  dicte  ecclesie,  quem  tunc  ob- 
tinuerat,  reddiderat  se  indignum,  ac  volens  dicto  Ricardo  gratiam  facere 
specialem,   voluit  et  concessit  certo  judici  dari  in   mandatis   ut   si  predictus 


LITERAE    PAPALES.  409 

Ricardus  eundeni  Gilbertum  super  premissis  coram  ipso  judice  accusare  seque 
in  forma  juris  inscribere  vellet,  postquam  dictum  Gilbertum  accusasset  seque 
inscripsisset,  ut  prefertur,  vocatis  dicto  Gilberto  et  aliis  qui  forent  evocandi 
super  premissis,  inquireret  auctoritate  apostolica  diligentius  veritatem,  et  si 
per  inquisitionem  hujusmodi  ea  invenerit  veritate  subniti,  dictum  Gilbertum 
eodem  archidiaconatu  auctoritate  prefata  sententialiter  privaret  .  .  .  prout  de 
jure  foret  faciendum ;  et  nihilominus  si  privationem  et  amotionem  predictas  per 
ipsum  judicem  fieri  contingeret,  dictum  archidiaconatum,  sive  per  privationem 
et  amotionem  hujusmodi  sive  alias  quovis  modo  vacaret,  prefato  Ricardo 
eadem  auctoritate  conferret  et  assignaret ;  dictoque  predecessore  sicut  Domino 
placuit  rebus  humanis  exempto,  et  nobis  divina  favente  clementia  ad  apicem 
summi  apostolatus  assumptis,  ne  dictus  Ricardus  voluntatis  et  concessionis 
hujusmodi,  pro  eo  quod  dicti  predecessoris  superveniente  obitu  litere  apostolice 
super  illis  confecte  non  fuerant,  frustraretur  effectu,  volumus  .  .  .  quod  prior 
voluntas  et  concessio  hujusmodi  ab  illarum  data  perinde  suum  sortirentur 
effectum,  ac  si  super  illis  ipsius  predecessoris  litere  sub  data  predicta  confecte 
fuissent,  quodque  nostre  super  ipsis  voluntate  et  concessione  confecte  ad  pro- 
bandum  plene  illas  ubique  sufficerent,  nec  ad  id  alterius  probationis  admini- 
culum  requireretur ;  et  ulterius  cum  dictus  Ricardus,  sicut  asserebat,  potentiam 
prefati  Gilberti  merito  perhorrescens,  eum  infra  Ciuitatem  Brechinensem  seu 
dictam  diocesim  nequiret  convenire  secure,  officiali  Sancti  Andree  suis  proprio 
nomine  non  expresso,  eisdem  nostris  dedimus  literis  in  mandatis  ut,  si  dictus 
Richardus  ipsum  Gilbertum  super  premissis  coram  eodem  officiali  accusaret, 
seque  in  forma  juris  inscribere  vellet  .  .  .  inquireret  auctoritate  nostra  dili- 
gentius  veritatem,  et  si  per  inquisitionem  hujusmodi  ea  inveniret  veritate 
subniti,  dictum  Gilbertum  archidiaconatu  predicto  eadem  auctoritate  nostra 
sententialiter  privaret,  et  amoveret  realiter  ab  eodem,  prout  de  jure  foret  faci- 
endum ;  et  si  privationem  et  amotionem  hujusmodi  per  dictum  officialem  fieri 
contingeret  eumdem  archidiaconatum,  sive  per  privationem  et  amotionem 
hujusmodi  tunc  sive  alias  quovis  modo  vacaret,  eidem  Ricardo  auctoritate 
nostra  prefata  conferret  et  assignaret,  juxta  priorem  voluntatem  et  conces- 
sionem  supradictas;  et  cum  dictus  Ricardus  vigore  literarum  earumdem  Gil- 
bertum  prefatum  super  hoc,  petendo  eum  prefato  archidiaconatu  sententialiter

privari  et.  ab  illo  amoveri,  ac  ipsum  archidiaconatum  sibi  conferri  et  assignari,

de  Cesarinis  etiam  cappellano  nostro  et  causarum  dicti  Palatii  auditori  audi-

quibus  assereretur  neutri  dictorura  Ricardi  et  Gilberti  in  dicto  archidiaconatu 

seu  ad  illum  jus  competere,  nos  causam  hujusmodi  coram  dicto  officiali  pen- 

dentem  advocantes  coram  dicto  Johanne  auditore  concessimus  dari  in  mandatis, 

literis  super  ipsa  concessionis  gratia  non  confectis,   ut  si  sibi   per  eventum

per  privationem  ejusdem   Gilberti  per  prefatum  episcopum  per  suam  diffini- 

tivam  sententiam,  que  nulla  provocatione  suspensa  in  rem  transivit  judicatam, 

auctoritate   ordinaria   propter   injectionem    manuum   hujusmodi   factam,    sive 

alias  quovis  modo  vacaret,  predicto   Ricardo  auctoritate  nostra  conferret  et 

assignaret ;  ipseque  Johannes  de  Cesai-inis  auditor  postmodum  in  causa  hujus- 

modi  ad  nonnuUos  actus,  citra  tamen  conclusionem  inter  partes  ipsas,  dicitur 

processisse ;  cum,  autem,  sicut  eadem  petitio  subjungebat,  prefatus  Gilbertus 

adhuc  in  possessione  dicti  archidiaconatus  existens,  lite  hujusmodi  coram  eodem 

Johanne  de  Cesarinis  sic  indecisa  pendente,  in  castro  Sancti  Quirini  Aretine 

diocesis  Romanam  curiam  sequendo  fuerit  vita  functus,  nos  statum  cause  hujus- 

modi,  necnon  orania  et  singula  beneficia  ecclesiastica  cum  cura  et  sine  cura  que 

dictus   Ricardus    in    quibuscumque    ecclesiis    sive    locis    ex    quibusvis    etiam 

apostolicis  dispensationibus  obtiuet  et  expectat  .  .  .  quecumque,  quotcumque.

ceptionem  vel  provisionem  alicujus  minime  teneantur  .  .  .  quodque  de  digni-

tionem,  et  qualibet  alia  dicte  sedis  indulgentia  generali  vel  speciali,  cujuscumque 
tenoris  existat,  per  quam  presentibus  non  expressam  vel  totaliter  non  insertara 
effectus  hujusmodi  gratie  impediri  valeat  quomodolibet  vel  differri,  et  de  qua 
cujusque  toto  tenore  habenda  sit  in  nostris  literis  mentio  specialis ;  aut  si 
dictus  Ricardus  presens  non  fuerit  ad  prestandum  de  observandis  statutis  et

Collatio  Georgii  Lydel  in  archidiaconatum  Brechinensem  . 

CCCCXXXIV.  Pius  II.  etc.  .  dilecto  filio  Georgio  Lydel  archidiacono  Ecclesie  Brechinensis 
bacdllario  in  decretis,  Salutem  etc.  .  Nobilitas  generis  vite  ac  morum  hon- 
estas  aliaque  laudabilia  probitatis  et  virtutum  merita,  super  quibus  apud  nos 
fidedigno  commendaris  testimonio,  nos  inducunt  ut  tibi  reddamur  ad  gratiam 
liberales  .  Dudum  siquidem  omnes  dignitates  ceteraque  beneficia  ecclesiastica 
cum  cura  et  sine  cura  quorumcumque  curialium,  quos  dum  Romana  Curia  de 
loco  ad  locum  transfertur  eam  sequendo  in  quovis  loco  quantumcumque  etiam 
a  dicta  Curia  remoto  decedere  contingeret,  tunc  vacantia  et  in  antea  vacatura 
collationi  et  dispositioni  nostre  reservavimus  .  .  .  Cum  itaque  postmodum 
archidiaconatus  ecclesie  Brechinensis  .  .  .  quem  quondam  Gilbertus  Forstar 
olim  ipsius  ecclesie  archidiaconus  dum  viveret  obtinebat,  per  obitum  ejusdem 
Gilberti,  qui  illum  obtinens  ac  noster  et  Sedis  Apostolice  acolitus  et  curialis 
existens  in  castro  Sancti  Quirini  ab  Abbatia  Sancti  Salvatoris  Clusinensis 
diocesis,  in  qua  cum  nostra  Curia  residebamus  ultra  duas  dietas  non  distante 
causa  recreationis,  permanens  diem  clausit  extremum,  vacavei-it  et  vacet  ad

Andree  diocesis  tempore  provisionis  et  perfectionis  hujusmodi  obtinebas,  prout

CCCCXXXVI.  BuU  by  Paul  II.  narrating  that,  having  heard  that  Richard  Wily,  archdeacon 
of  Brechin  and  collector  of  the  revenues  of  the  Apostolic  Chamber  in  these 
parts,  was  desirous  to  serve  the  Lord  as  a  regular  monk  in  the  monastery  of 
the  blessed  Mary  of  Calco,  or  Kelso,  belonging  to  the  order  of  St.  Benedict 
and  in  the  diocese  of  St.  Andrews,  he  had  by  other  letters  commanded  certain 
judges  to  receive  the  said  Richard  as  a  monk  and  friar,  if  he  were  fit  and 
there  were  no  canonical  obstacle,  to  give  him  the  regular  habit,  according  to 
the  custom  of  the  said  monastery,  to  treat  him  therein  with  all  sincere  kind- 
ness  in  the  Lord,  and  to  receive  from  him  the  profession  usually  made  by  the 
monss  of  the  said  monastery,  if  he  were  willing  of  his  own  accord  to  make 
the  same  in  suis  ordinibus ;  that  so  soon  as  the  said  Richard  had  taken  the 
habit,  or  made  this  profession,  or  a  year  of  his  probation  had  elapsed,  or  even 
previously,  if  it  appeared  he  was  willing  to  change  his  life  altogether,  or 


LITERAE    PAPALES.  415 

if  he  assumed  the  habit,  and  conducted  himself  as  a  pi'ofessor  foi'  the  space 
of  three  days,  he  should  be  bound  to  demit  all  his  ecclesiastical  benefices  with 
or  without  cure ;  and  when  therefore,  in  this  way,  the  perpetual  vicarage  of 
the  painsh  church  of  Dunde,  and  the  parish  church  or  rectory  of  Kinel,  belong- 
ing  to  the  dioceses  of  Brechin  and  St.  Andrews  and  held  by  the  said  Richard, 
were  expected  to  become  vacant,  the  Pope,  in  accordance  with  the  tenor  of 
former  letters  of  indulgence  granted  by  him  to  John  Spalding,  dean  of  Brechin, 
and  for  the  sake  of  James,  King  of  Scots,  who  had  sought  not  only  these 
benefices,  but  also  the  bishopric  of  Dunkeld  for  the  said  John  Spalding,  his 
councillor,  confessor,  and  master  of  his  chapel,  confeiTed,  and  hereby  confers,  the 
said  vicarage  and  rectory,  with  the  yearly  revenues  thereof,  which  did  not  exceed 
thirty  pounds  sterling  for  each,  ou  the  said  John  Spalding  ;  allowing  him  to  hold 
these  two  incompatible  benefices  in  conjunction  with  the  deanery  for  three  years, 
to  resign  the  three  all  at  once  or  one  by  one  successively  at  his  pleasure, 
whether  this  were  simply  or  for  the  sake  of  exchange,  to  receive  in  their  stead 
three  other  incompatible  benefices,  among  which  these  two  may  be  reckoned, 
not  being,  however,  parish  churches,  or  their  perpetual  vicarages,  and  to  hold 
these  two,  to  wit,  the  parish  church  and  viearage,  for  seven  years,  and  the  third, 
if  one  of  the  three  is  not  previously  exchanged  for  a  compatible  benefice,  for  three 
years,  he  being  bound  in  case  of  no  such  exchange,  wholly  to  demit,  at  the  end 
of  the  said  three  years,  that  one  of  the  three  which  he  first  got ;  and  that  not- 
withstanding  the  same  Pope  had  prohibited,  with  certain  exceptions,  any  person 
from  holding  together  two  parochial  churches  or  two  dignities,  being  either  those 
immediately  under  the  episcopal  in  cathedral  churches  or  the  principal  in  col- 
legiate  churches,  unless  the  parish  churches  were  so  contiguous  as  to  be  con- 
veniently  served  by  one  person,  and  unless,  also,  their  revenues  did  not  exceed 
the  yearly  value  of  twenty-four  gold  florins  of  the  chamber ;  dispensing  with 
all  ecclesiastical  statutes  and  customs  to  the  contrary ;  but  providing  that  the 
foresaids  deanery,  vicarage,  and  church,  should  not  be  defrauded  of  the  services 
due  to  them ;  and  directing  the  bishops  of  Glasgow  and  Galloway,  and  the  dean 
of  Rheims,  to  give  the  said  John  Spalding  possession  of  the  saids  benefices 
accordingly.     Dated  at  St.  Marks,  at  Rome,  I9th  November,  1467. 


416  LITERAE    PAPALES. 


CCCCXXXVII.  Mandate  by  Clement  VII.  to  the  bisliops  of  Caserta  and  Aberdeen,  ^d  to 
Gilbert  Strathauchin,  canon  of  Aberdeen,  to  induct  James  Pitcairn  inta"  the 
corporal  possession  of  the  archdeaconry  of  Brechin,  to  which  the  Pope  had 
presented  him,  on  the  resignation  thereof  by  David  Pitcairn,  the  former 
archdeacon.  Dated  at  St.  Peters,  in  Rome,  8th  October,  in  the  third  year  of 
tlie  Pope's  Pontificate,  1526. 


ROTULI  REDITUUM  EPISCOPATUS. 


CCCCXXXVIII.  COMPOTUM  DOMINI  HENRICI  DE  KINGORN,  SENESCALLI  DO- 
MINE  REGINE  ET  CAMERARII  DE  GARVIACH  ET  BRECHIN, 
redditum  apud  Edinburgh  vndecimo  die  mensis  Augusti  anno  Domini 
millesimo  quadringentesimo  sexagesimo  secundo,  de  omnibus  rcceptis  suis

CCCCXXXIX.  COMPOTUM  DOMINI  WILLELMI  RYNDE,  RECEPTOmS  FIRMARUM 
DOMINII  DE  BRECHIN  et  de  Nevar,  redditum  apud  Edinburgh  vicesimo 
octauo  die  mensis  Julii  anno  Domini  millesimo  quadringentesimo  sexa- 
gesimo  tertio,  de  omnibus  receptis  suis  et  expensis  ab  vndecimo  die  mensis 
Augusti  anno  Domini  millesimo  quadringentesimo  sexagesimo  secundo, 
vsque  in  diem  presentis  compoti;  et  sic  de  duobus  terminis  infra  hoc 
compotum  . 

In  primis,  compotans  onerat  se  de  xvlib.  xii  s.  de  firmis  terrarum  de  Pencostane

V  lib.  vii  s.  viii  d.  de  dimidietate  terrarum  de  En*ot  in  dicto  dominio,  de  dictis  ter- 
minis ;  et  de  iiii  lib.  xiii  s.  iiii  d.  de  firmis  molendini  de  Errot,  per  dictum  tempus  ; 
et  de  xl  lib,  per  integras  firmas  terre  de  Kincrag  et  Balbirny,  cum  molendino 
eiusdem,  de  dictis  terminis ;  et  de  xviii  lib.  xii  s.  viii  d.  de  firmis  terrarum  de 
Balnabreich,  de  eisdem  terminis ;  et  de  vi  lib.  xii  s.  viii  d.  [de  firmis]  terre  de 
Buthirgill,  de  dictis  terminis ;  et  de  xiiii  lib.  xii  d.  de  firmis  terrarum  de  Pet- 
poUokis,  per  idem  tempus ;  et  de  x  lib.  de  firmis  terre  de  Kindrochet,  et  de  x  bollis 
avenarum,  et  ii  duodenis  gallinarum,  per  idem  tempus  .  Item,  idem  onerat  se  de

quadraginta  sex  solidos  et  octo  denarios,  vt  asserit  compotans,  xlyi  s.  viii  d.  ; 
et  abbati  de  Cupro,  percipienti  anuuatira  sex  solidos  octo  denarios  de  fabrili 
de  Brechin,  vt  asserit  idem  compotans,  vi  s.  viii  d. ;  et  Alexandro  de  Setoun, 
percipienti  annuatim  quadraginta  solidos  annui  redditus  de  Kincrac  sibi  eciam 
debitos,  de  duobus  terminis  huius  compoti,  xls.;  et  priori  de  Restinot,  pro 
secundis  decimis  sibi  debitis  de  dictis  terris  de  Brechin  et  Nevar,  Regi  perti- 
nentibus  per  forisfacturam  quondam  comitis  Atholie,  de  dictis  duobus  terminis, 
xiiii  lib.  xiii  s.  viii  d. ;  et  eidem  per  solucionem  factam  Johanni  Haukirstoun 
ad  fabricam  collegii  Sancti  Saluatoris  per  manus  domini  Henrici  de  Kingorn, 
de  quibus  idem  Johannes  reddidit  compotum,  lii  lib.  xvi  s.  x  d. ;  et  eidem  per 
solucionem  factam  dicto  Johanni  Haukirstoun  ad  dictam  fabricam,  et  de 
quibus  idem  Johannes  reddidit  compotum,  Ixxxvii  lib.  vii  s.  vi  d. ;  et  eidem 
per  solueionem  factam  Edvv^ardo  Boncle  ad  dictam  fabricam,  vt  patet  per  librum 
dicti  Edwardi  sua  propria  manu  scriptum,  ostensum  super  compotum,  Ixlib., 
pro  quibus  idem  respondebit ;  et  eidem  per  solucionem  factam  domino  Henrico 
de  Kingorn,  senescallo  Regine,  ad  expensas  eiusdem,  ipso  fatente  receptum 
super  compotum,  et  pro  quibus  respondebit,  xxiiii  lib.  xiii  s.  ii  d. ;  et  eidem  pro 
reparacione  molendini  de  Nevar,  ex  mandato,  xl  s. ;  et  eidem  pro  le  inlac  vic- 
tualium  venditorum,  cum  quibus  compotans  superius  oneratur,  xxv  s. ;  et  eidem 
in  xviii  martis  cum  coriis,  emptis  per  eundem  et  liberatis  ad  expensas  Domine 
Regine,  quarum  restant  trea  in  lardinaria  de  Rav}'nniscrag,  et  alie  quindecim 
locantur  in  herbagio,  videlicet,  quatuor  cum  Herbarto  de  Morauia  in  le  Pullis, 
et  sex  in  armento  Domine  Regine  in  Lossintrule,  et  relique  quinque  locantur 
per  senescallum  Kingorn,  pro  quibus  respondebit,  precium  pecie  xv  s.  iiii  d., 
summa  xiii  lib.  xvi  s. ;  et  eidem  pi-o  secundis  decimis  debitis  priori  de  Rostinet 
de  le  Halch,  alias  in  manibus  Domine  Regine,  nou  scriptis  in  rentali,  xiii  s.  iiii  d. ; 
et  eidem  pro  feodo  suo,  ex  consideracione  auditorum,  L  s. ;  et  per  solucionem

ceptum]  super  compotum,  et  pro  quibus  respondebit,  iii  lib.  viii  s.  ii  d.

BRECHIN,  both  spiritualitie  and  temporalitie,  as  it  is  in  use  of  pay-

CCCCXLIL  APUD  EDINBURGH  vigesimo  primo  Januarij  anno  Domini  M  vj"  xiij.  FOR- 
SAMEKIL  as  in  our  soverane  lordis  Parhament,  haldin  at  Edinburfh  in 
the  moneth  of  October  last  hypast,  thair  wes  commission  gevin  to  ane 
nomber  of  noblemen,  prelattis,  commissioneris  of  shyres  and  burrowis,  and 
officeris  of  estate,  to  see  and  consider  the  taxt  rollis,  quhairupoun  any 
persone  hes  bene  chargit  heirtofoir  to  mak  payment  of  any  bygane  taxa- 
tionis  grantit  to  his  Majestie,  and  to  mak  a  perfite  taxt  roll,  quhairupoun 
all  chargis  sal  be  heireftir  directit  agains  any  of  his  hienes  liegis,  for 
payment  of  thair  pairtis  of  the  taxatioun  grantit  to  his  Majestie  in  the 
same  Parliament,  as  in  the  same  Act  of  Parliament  at  lenth  is  contenit : 
THE  SAIDS  LORDS  COMMISSIONERS  haveing  convenit  togidder  for 
that  effect,  and  having  exactly  tryed  and  examined  the  same  rollis,  Finds, 
Deceens,  and  Declaeis,  that  thair  is  contenit  within  the  same  the  noniber 
of  landis  efter  specifiet,  haldin  blanche  ward  and  relief  of  his  Majestie, 
and  ar  lyable  to  the  payment  of  his  Majesties  taxacionis  ;  They  ae  to 
SAY ;  THE  Taxt  Eoll  of  the  shirefdom  of  Forfar,  gevin  in  to  the  com- 
missioneris  of  Parliament,  upon  the  twentie-ane  day  of  Januar  M  vj^^  and

APUD  EDIN.  xxj  Januarij,  1613.  THIS  TAXT  ROLL  producit  befoir 
the  Lordis  Commissioneris  of  Parliament  under  subseryvand  be 
George  Wardlaw,  ShirefF-Clerk  of  Foi-far,  who  made  faith  that  the 
same  is  just  and  trew  according  to  his  knowledge.  Sie  subseribitur— 
Dunkeld — Robert  Lord  Lyndsay — Sir  Thonias  Hamiltoun — Alex''' 
Hay — Sir  Gedeoun  Murray — Kynnaird — Sir  James  Weymes  of  Bogie — 
Mr.  Alex""-  Wedderburne — John  Lockhart  of  Barr.  Extracted  out  of 
the  Eecords  of  Taxt  Eoils  in  the  Lower  Parliament  House,  upon  this 
and  the  prcceding  five  pages,  by  Mr.  Thomas  Gibsone  one  of  thie 
principal  Clerks  of  Session,  as  haveing  conimission  for  that  effect 
ii'om  the  Lord  Clerk  Register. 

^Signed)  Tho.  Gibsone.

I  unflcrsiibscriber  do  hereby  declare  that  the  preceding  pages  do  contain 
the  just  double  of  the  rental  given  to  me  by  the  deceast  Jobn  Spence,  clerk  of 
Breichen  and  my  factor,  for  uplifting  my  rents,  and  has  been  compareJ  by 
George  Spence  his  sou,  principall  clerk,  and  is  the  rule  by  which  his  father  and 
he  did  compt  with  me  for  my  saids  rents,  cropes  and  years  1685  and  168G 
years.  There  is  also  the  sum  of  five  hundreth  raerks  Scots  money  yearly 
payed  by  .  .  .  Scot  of  Ancrum  to  the  Bishops  of  Bi-eichen,  and  -whilk  five 
hundred  merks  was  payed  to  me  ;  and  this  besides  some  sniall  fewduties 
payable  out  of  houses  and  tenements  in  the  city  of  Bi'eichen,  a  fuU  conipleat 
and  exact  accompt  wbereof  at  present  I  cannot  give  ;  all  which  may  be  liere- 
after  inquired  by  those  who  are  concerneJ.  I  do  furthei'  declare  that  I  payed 
yearly  to  the  minister  of  Breichen,  out  of  my  saids  rents,  three  hundred  anJ 
iifty  merks  Scots  money,  as  a  part  of  his  stipenJ  yearly.  The  forewritten 
rental  is  attesteJ  by  me  in  presence  of  James  Coway,  principall  bailie  of 
Breichen,  and  is  all  that  I  know  or  consists  with  my  knowledge  thereanont : 
and  all  which  I  declare  to  be  a  truth,  as  I  shall  answer  to  God.  In  witness 
whereof,  thir  presents  are  subscribed  by  the  saiJ  James  Covvay  and  me,  at 
Broichin  the  20th  day  of  December  1689.- 

Ja.  Deummond. 
Ja.  Coway,  Bailii:.
